title: Welcome
text:
Introduction on Redesign Project
This project examines two visualizations representing the percentage of American youth ages 17-24 who are ineligible for military service. The initial visualization analyzed was obtained from the White House MAHA (Make America Healthy Again) Report [1]. The first original graph, while a simple pie chart, it contains several limitations in clarity, readability, and analytical values. Consequently, I sought to redesign and enhance the visualization to improve its interpretability and adherence the effective data visualization principle.
To locate the underlying data, I reviewed the report’s cited sources which references the Joint Advertising, Market Research & Studies (JAMRS) program. However, many of the reference links were inactive or no longer accessible. One reference led to StrongNation.org [2] where I identified a related visualization that served as the basis for a secondary redesign within this project.
Because the original dataset could not be retrieved, I manually reconstructed the data using numerical values extracted directly from the published graphics. The recreated dataset was then analyzed and visualization redesigned. This process enabled the development of new, data-driven visualizations that more effectively convey the underlying patterns and improve upon the design and interpretive shortcomings of the original charts.


Presentation


Sources Information
[1] JAMRS, 2020 Youth Report (as cited in The White House – MAHA Report, May 22, 2025). https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/MAHA-Report-The-White-House.pdf 
[2] Department of Defense (2017), as cited by Mission: Readiness – Council for a Strong America. Retrieved from https://www.strongnation.org/articles/414-map-many-young-americans-are-ineligible-to-serve-in-the-military

title: Visualization One
text:
Original Visualization




Figure 1





The original pie chart below was designed to communicate the distribution of reasons American youth (ages 17 - 24) are ineligible for military service. The purpose was to compare the proportion of eligible versus ineligible youth. The breakdown was further divided by specific reasons for ineligibility disqualification.
While the intention of the chart is clear the design significantly limits comprehension. The image quality is low, the color choices are inconsistent, and the layout does not effectively communicate proportions or comparisons.




Image Quality: The original chart was pixelated and difficult to read, like the one above. Context like the not on Drug Abuse DQ is illegible.
Formatting: The inconsistent font size and colors create visual clutter.
Color Use: Each wedge of the pie chart hac a unique color but with no clear meaning. Adjacent segments use similar and different hues, making them hard to distinguish or understand.
Chart Type: A pie chart is not ideal for comparing many categories. Especially with several categories represent 1%.
Visual communication: The design fails to guide the eye toward the most important information. Nearly half of youths are disqualified for multiple reasons and that is in gray easily missed.

title: Visualization Two
text:
Original Visualization




The original visualization was designed to communicate the percentage of young Americans ages 17 to 24 who are ineligible to join the military across the United States. The intent was to raise awareness of the magnitude of ineligibility and highlight the top preventable causes in a geographic visualization.
While the design is eye-catching the use of a hexagonal tile map and color grouping makes the visualization appealing but analytically weak. The view can quickly grasp that most stats have high ineligibility rate (around 70%) but comparing individual states or seeing subtle differences can be difficult.
Note regarding text design elements: Nearly half of the visualization functions as a text legend displaying exact percentages, organized from highest to lowest. This layout may be misleading, as viewers naturally read from left to right. Potentially assuming the values increase in that direction. Since most states fall into the lower percentage ranges, this arrangement can create the false impression at a quick glance that a majority of states are in the higher-percentage category.



Color Binning: States are grouped into broad color ranges (e.g., 62-70%). This hides the exact values and diminishes interpretive accuracy.
Chart Type: The hex map layout distorts geography states and can mislead when trying to interpret reginal clusters.
Legend: Text-heavy design elements. The image provides little specific data unless the viewer reads small text annotations below.
Scale: Small differences like 70% to 71% appear as sharp visual jumps.

title: Code
text:
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(forcats)

Eligibility <- data.frame(
  Category = c("Meets All Criteria","Multiple Disqualifiers","Medical/Physical",
               "Overweight","Mental Health","Drug Abuse",
               "Conduct","Dependents","Aptitude"),
  Percent  = c(23, 44, 7, 11, 4, 8, 1, 1, 1)
)

lev_order <- c("Meets All Criteria","Dependents","Conduct","Aptitude",
               "Mental Health","Medical/Physical","Drug Abuse",
               "Overweight","Multiple Disqualifiers")

Eligibility <- Eligibility %>%
  mutate(
    Category = factor(Category, levels = lev_order),
    Group = case_when(
      Category == "Meets All Criteria" ~ "Eligible",
      TRUE ~ "Ineligible"))

ggplot(Eligibility, aes(x = Category, y = Percent, fill = Group)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.8) +
  coord_flip() +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(Percent, "%")), hjust = -0.1, size = 4) +
  annotate("segment", x = 1.5, xend = 1.5, y = 0, yend = 50,
           linewidth = 0.7, color = "#4B0000") +
  labs(
    title = "Military Eligibility Among U.S. Youth (2020)",
    x = "Eligibility Status Reasoning",
    y = "Percentage of Youth (ages 17-24)",
    caption = "Source: JAMRS, 2020 Youth Report [2]",
    fill = "Eligibility Status"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50), expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0))) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Ineligible" = "#9a031e",
      "Eligible" = "#2CA58D"
    ),
    breaks = c("Ineligible", "Eligible") 
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 8) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold", color = "#4B0000", hjust = 0.3),
    axis.title.x = element_text(size = 14, color = "#4B0000", margin = margin(t = 10)),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 14, color = "#4B0000", margin = margin(r = 10)),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, color = "#4B0000"),
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10, color = "#4B0000"),
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 10, hjust = 0, color = "#4B0000", margin = margin(t = 8, l = 2)),
    plot.margin = margin(10, 20, 10, 20),
    legend.position = "right",
    legend.direction = "vertical",
    legend.title = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold", color = "#4B0000"),
    legend.text = element_text(size = 10, color = "#4B0000")
  )

title: Visualization One
text:
Redesign One










Redesign One Purpose
To recreate and improve this visualization I sourced and cleaned the 2020 JAMRS data manually based on the original chart values. Resign emphasized proportional understanding of the data. This redesign aimed to create a direct comparison between eligibility categories while retaining all key original data points.
This redesign makes it clear that nearly half of youth (44%) are ineligible due to multiple disqualifying factors. It also highlights that overweight and drug use are key single-factor disqualifies. The redesign graph conveys the same information from the original but is visually cleaner and focused.

Improvements

Switched from a pie chart to a horizontal bar chart to improve comparison.
Grouped the data logically by placing “Meet All Criteria” at bottom.
Used color coding to separate “eligible” and “Ineligible” for immediate visual contrast.
Renamed labels for clarity and added clear title, axis labels, and percentages.

title: Visualization One
text:
Redesign Two










Redesign Two Purpose
The second redesign builds upon the first but focuses solely on ineligible youth. To allow for proportional scaling I updated by population count given in the original graph of 32,878,937 youth.
While this graph changed the original focus from comparing the proportion of eligible verses ineligible youth, I felt that this design better communicated the magnitude of disqualification by type. It shows that “Multiple Disqualifiers” vastly outweighs other categories. The simplified focus helps clarify both scale and impact.

Improvements

Converted percentages to actual population count (in millions).
Simplified the chart to focus only on disqualifying factors.
Grouped 1% categories into an “Other (≤1%)” segment with a clear footnote.
Refined color gradient to represent severity.

title: Visualization One
text:
Conclusion
Across the redesigns clarity and interpretability improved dramatically. The first redesign emphasized the eligible/ ineligible split. The second redesign focused on scale and significance withing the ineligible population.
For future improvements integrating a time-series component (e.g., trends from 2010-2020) could further strengthen public understanding of military eligibility trends.

The intent was to raise awareness of the magnitude of ineligibility and highlight the top preventable causes in a geographic visualization.

Weaknesses of Original Graph

Color Binning: States are grouped into broad color ranges (e.g., 62-70%). This hides the exact values and diminishes interpretive accuracy.
Chart Type: The hex map layout distorts geography states and can mislead when trying to interpret reginal clusters.

Redesign








Redesign Purpose
The redesign aims to provide an accurate and interactive visualization of the percentage of youth ineligibility for military service by state.
This redesign makes reginal patterns immediately clear. The Sothern states like MS, LA, AL, and GA shows the highest ineligibility rates. While the Midwestern and Northeastern states show slightly lower rates. This map provides precise data points rather than broad categories. This encourages accurate interpretation and reginal analysis.

Improvements

Adopted a true geographic projection.
Applied a continuous color scale for better distinction.
Added hover text for each state to deliver specific values without clutter.
Simplified layout to center focus on the data itself.
Made the chart interactive. Allowing users to explore details.

title: Visualization Two
text:
Conclusion
This redesign transforms a static infographic map into exploration and analysis. It strengthens accuracy and user engagement while maintaining the message of the original report.
Future enhancements Could include overlays for the major contributing factors like obesity and drug use. Allowing policymakers to visualize where the issue is most severe.
